text: We're from the local secondary school.
Welcome to One Way or Another, the interactive experience!
You will get to explore different topics that affect women, girls and non-binary people.
You'll be given a scenario about each topic. There are no right answers, but it's your job to make decisions!
We're from the local secondary school.
You've just found one of the barn's interactive experience stations!
Around the barn, you will find different stations relating to topics that affect women, girls and non-binary people.
You'll be given a scenario at each station. It's your job to make decisions!

attitudes.text: You arrive at school and go straight to your form room. When you sit down, you can hear boys at the back of the room watching a video and making sexist comments.
You ignore them. The boys continue to joke, getting louder. It makes you feel very uncomfortable.

attitudes.text1: No one calls them out, and they continue to make jokes all day. Other boys start to get involved too.
attitudes.text2: The boys laugh and call you boring. It doesn’t stop them. After all, the guy they’re watching makes the same jokes and has millions of fans.
attitudes.quote:
92% of girls stated that they received sexist name-calling ‘a lot’ or ‘sometimes’ between people their age*

*A 2021 Ofsted survey of 32 schools and colleges

attitudes.title: But, there is good news
attitudes.text: In 2012, British feminist writer Laura Bates founded The Everyday Sexism project. The site allows people to submit experiences of sexism from around the world. The accounts are collated by a small group of volunteers and shared for all to see.

attitudes.title: Tips for if you're a man
attitudes.text: Don't be a bystander. If your friends are making sexist jokes, call them out. You become part of the problem when you don’t speak up.

safety.text: On your walk home from school, a group of men in a car start driving slowly next to you, shouting rude comments.
You ignore them. The car continues to follow you and they keep shouting at you.

safety.text1:
You ignore them and they keep following you. Luckily, you find a shop and run inside.

They all laugh when I do.
safety.text2:
You shout back at them. They become more aggressive and start threatening you until you find a shop and run inside.

They all laugh when you do.
safety.quote:
35% of females aged 14-21 have experienced unwanted sexual attention or harassment in a public place while wearing a school uniform*

*A Plan International UK survey

safety.title: But, there is good news
safety.text: Campaign groups have managed to get a bill that would make street harassment illegal debated in parliament. However, as of the 24th of March 2023, it does not explicitly make public sexual harassment a crime, and the victim still has to prove that the perpetrator intended to cause distress or harm.

safety.title: Tips for if you're a man
safety.text: Try to be aware of situations where women may feel unsafe. Be an active bystander - if you see that a woman is uncomfortable, ask if she is okay.

environment.text: You’re walking home after school. It’s winter, so it’s already dark outside. The park you normally walk through doesn’t have any lighting or CCTV.
You begin to walk through the park, it's dark and you can't see much. You hear a group of people up ahead.

environment.text1: You continue to walk through the park, as walking round the outside takes longer. Luckily, the group of people don't bother you, but you're scared as you walk past. You don't want to feel like this all winter.
environment.text2: You walk round the outside of the park. Whilst you made it back safely, it takes 20 minutes longer. You don't want to have this added journey time all winter.
environment.quote:
28% of women steer clear of certain areas and 21% avoid being out at certain times to protect themselves. By contrast, only 14% of men avoid certain areas, and 9% avoid being out at certain times.*

*A 2018 YouGov survey

environment.title: But, there is good news
environment.text: Bradford has teamed up with safety app WalkSafe+. The app brings police crime data and community reported data together, allowing the user to plan safer journeys and understand local crime hotspots, as well as share their journey with family and friends so they can monitor their safe arrival, sending automatic alerts if they fail to reach their destination.

environment.title: Tips for if you're a man
environment.text: You can help make women safer by being aware of your surroundings. If it's dark, keep your distance and don't make any sudden movements towards women.

health.text: In a lesson, you get your period. At first your teacher doesn't let you go to the toilet as “it’s just been breaktime”. When they let you go, you realise that you don’t have any pads or tampons. There is no one else in the bathroom for you to ask.
You wait, but after a few minutes, you worry you’ll get into trouble if you wait any longer.

health.text1: Your teacher sends someone to find you. Luckily they have a tampon on them, but you get into trouble for taking too long when you're back at your lesson.
health.text2: You use toilet paper as a temporary solution. When you get back to your lesson, you get a tampon but your teacher won’t let you go to the toilet again. You find it hard to concentrate as you’re worried about your period. You go to the loo before your next lesson, but get into trouble for being late.
health.quote:
35% of girls aged 13-18 have taken time off school or college because they have their period*

*A study by PHS Group with 250 young people

health.title: But, there is good news
health.text: In January 2020, the UK government launched its Period Products Scheme, which allows education organisations in England to order free period products. Since the scheme’s launch, 94% of secondary schools and 90% post-16 organisations in England now provide free period products to pupils.

health.title: Tips for if you're a man
health.text: Periods are a normal, healthy monthly routine that girls experience. Tackle period stigma by never making a girl ashamed about having her period.

finish.attitudes: How do you think attitudes would be different if the world around us was built by women?
finish.safety: How do you think safety would be different if the world around us was built by women?
finish.environment: How do you think the environment would be different if the world around us was built by women?
finish.health: How do you think our health would be different if the world around us was built by women?
finish.textQr: Write your thoughts on the blackboard, and then find another station.
finish.textOnline: Have a chat to your friends about your thoughts.
